docs.lead_paragraph: Nixzaliz Santiago left the small coastal town in Puerto Rico where her family lived when she was a teenager and came to New York in the mid-1990's. Already with a young son, Javier, she found a new love and became pregnant again. The father wanted her to end the pregnancy, Ms. Santiago's relatives said, but she would not, and on July 18, 1998, a girl was born. Her mother named her Nixzmary.
docs.snippet: Nixzaliz Santiago left the small coastal town in Puerto Rico where her family lived when she was a teenager and came to New York in the mid-1990's.

byline.original: By KAREEM FAHIM; Janon Fisher contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Men's Abortion Rights,'' by John Tierney (column, Jan. 10):

headline.main: Must Men Have a Say In Abortion Choices?

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Men's Abortion Rights,'' by John Tierney (column, Jan. 10):

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Men's abortion rights'' is an oxymoron. Men cannot have abortions, and they should not have the legal right to control the outcome of a pregnancy, regardless of their financial or legal relationship with the mother.

headline.main: Must Men Have a Say In Abortion Choices?

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     ''Men's abortion rights'' is an oxymoron. Men cannot have abortions, and they should not have the legal right to control the outcome of a pregnancy, regardless of their financial or legal relationship with the mother.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: John Tierney doesn't mention the obvious in his discussion of men who don't wish to become parents or pay child support for 18 years: the man can always wear a condom.

headline.main: Must Men Have a Say In Abortion Choices?

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     John Tierney doesn't mention the obvious in his discussion of men who don't wish to become parents or pay child support for 18 years: the man can always wear a condom.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kari Wuhrer, an actress who formerly appeared on the ABC soap opera ''General Hospital,'' sued ABC Productions and American Broadcasting Companies on Thursday, saying that the producers of the show killed off her character and dismissed her last August because she was pregnant. In documents filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Ms. Wuhrer, who started on ''General Hospital'' last January, says that she was told by a producer of the show that the writers had refused to accommodate her pregnancy and that she was dismissed because of it. She also asserts that her case reflects a systemic anti-pregnancy attitude on ABC soap operas and that actresses on the daytime programs are left with the choice to either terminate their pregnancies or lose their jobs.

headline.main: In Suit, Actress Says Pregnancy Led to Firing

docs.abstract: Actress Kari Wuhrer sues ABC, saying that producers of television show General Hospital killed off her character and dismissed her because she was pregnant; claims that her case reflects systemic anti-pregnancy attitude of ABC soap operas; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Kari Wuhrer, formerly of "General Hospital," sued ABC on Thursday, saying that the producers fired her because she was pregnant.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the Senate Judiciary Committee's confirmation hearing yesterday for Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr., President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court. He was questioned by, among others, Senators Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois; Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas; Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa; Mike DeWine, Republican of Ohio; and Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York. The statements were recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript: nytimes.com/supremecourt. Abortion SENATOR DURBIN -- Well, this is what troubles me: that you do not see Roe as a natural extension of Griswold, that you do not see the privacy rights of Griswold extended by the decision in Roe, that you've decided to create categories of cases that are -- have been decided by the court that you will concede have constitutional protection, but you have left in question the future of Roe v. Wade.

headline.main: 'Private Religious Speech Can't Be Discriminated Against'

docs.snippet: Following are excerpts from the Senate Judiciary Committee's confirmation hearing yesterday for Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr., President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court. He was questioned by, among others, Senators Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Indignation Is The Sincerest Form, Etc., Etc. ''You know,'' PAUL REISER was telling us at Tavern on the Green on Tuesday night, before the National Board of Review awards ceremony, where he was about to be the M.C., ''the great thing is, it's not on TV, so if it doesn't go well, who's going to know? GEORGE CLOONEY? Who cares?'' A valid point and a profound one. If famous people are around and they are not filmed, were they ever there? Further, if JANE FONDA's publicist doesn't want her to talk to reporters, is the publicist really a publicist?
docs.snippet: If famous people are around and they are not filmed, were they ever there?

byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON; With Paula Schwartz

docs.lead_paragraph: JANINE CARPENTER arrived at Columbia University in September with a complexion as clear as her bright blue eyes. But during her first month of college, her face began breaking out in pimples and deep, inflamed nodules, the same symptoms that had plagued her early in high school in San Jose, Calif. ''My acne just immediately started to come back at a really rapid rate,'' Ms. Carpenter, 18, said. So her doctor gave her the potent acne drug isotretinoin, best known as Accutane. The prescription came with a bright yellow label assuring the pharmacist that Ms. Carpenter was not pregnant, because Accutane can cause severe birth defects. She agreed to also have a pregnancy test each month before refilling her prescription, even though she takes birth control pills. These precautions were part of a program organized by the makers of Accutane and other brands of isotretinoin (Amnesteem, Claravis and Sotret) meant to prevent pregnancy in women taking the drug.

headline.main: Doctors Fear Acne Drug Rules Go Too Far

docs.snippet: New rules for taking isotretinoin are meant to prevent birth defects, but are so strict they might discourage many patients from using the drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: This week's trip to New York could have been billed as a victory lap for Beverley Hughes, the British minister of state for children, young people and families. For while many American educators and policy experts have spent four decades in a slow push for universal prekindergarten programs and affordable child care, Britain's Labor government has leapt into the full agenda.

headline.main: The Need to Invest in Young Children

docs.abstract: Beverley Hughes, British minister of state for children, young people and families, addresses New York City conference on early childhood education; British efforts, which are relatively new, have surpassed any programs in United States in terms of scope and economic impact; other speakers discuss changes they feel are necessary to improve education in US; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Sure Start, Britain's version of Head Start, is expanding rapidly, while the U.S. government is considering budget cuts for Head Start.

docs.lead_paragraph: Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. said Tuesday that he would bring an open mind to the Supreme Court when it came to abortion rights and sought to rebut suggestions that he had an overly expansive view of presidential powers as he parried a barrage of questions at the heart of his confirmation battle. In his first public give and take with the 10 Republicans and 8 Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Judge Alito made no glaring mistakes as he engaged in a day of sparring with Democrats who are concerned that he would move the court to the right on some of the most divisive issues facing the nation.

headline.main: Alito, at Hearing, Pledges an Open Mind on Abortion

docs.snippet: Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. said that he would bring an open mind to the Supreme Court when it came to abortion rights.

byline.original: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and NEIL A. LEWIS
